First we could not enjoy the Sunday buffet {our fault as we showed up at 11:30am} so we would have to eat at the restaurant,err don't do that,food sucked and was way over priced.Better of to take your own food and have a little picnic in the parking lot. Where have all the animals gone?? Many look like they have parasite problem especially the ostriches and turkeys. The viticulture display was just deplorable,looked like it has had no attention for a long time,on display was in pieces and filled with ants,definitely no worms there. Overall,we where very disappointed and i think other are too as the only people we saw where drawn to the breakfast buffet,there was next to no one else in the part. We go to leave,having to pass through the main entrance and here is some dude laid back in a chain with his feet on the desk,nice impression to leave on tourist there bud. I would think that Sat and Sun would be money days for such a place as Malogos gardens,looks like it is a loosing proposition now.Very sad !!  PS the bathrooms in the customer parking lot,well,just don't go there.
The place has all the variety of flora like orchids, dendrobiums, and even dragon fruit. Davao is fertile for all kinds of flowers.

I really enjoyed Malagos for 5 days so did my family, its a very peaceful place to relax and there restaurant has decent prices and ok food. The whole garden is very clean and the plants well maintained. But i do also need to point...More
Took a day visit of the property and enjoyed the few orchids that were in bloom and the butterfly exhibit. Location is on the way to the Eagle Center and recommend a stop on the way up or back.

ReviewTitle: A very nice place to commune with nature
Review: Be there for a day tour or stay overnight whichever pleased you. But for us we stayed overnight also to visit the Philippine Eagle Center. The two places are just so close that if you like, you can walk for a kilometer. The garden resort...More

ReviewTitle: Malagos garden resort a good place to experience new.
Review: Malagos Garden Resort is one of the most frequented destinations in Davao City. Malagos Garden Resort is a nature retreat for the whole family. ... If you are a nature lover, they have landscaped gardens with different trees and flowers.

Location: General Santos City, General Santos, Philippines
Review: the place is very advisable to visit specially if you have children with you or if you are in an educational field trip. because they set a side a time to have a lecture in the different kinds of animals that they have. the place...More

ReviewTitle: A pity they don't maintain the sculptures of National Artist Napoleon Abueva
Review: Birds: ok. Plants: ok. Other animals: need extra care and upkeep. But here's the ultimate critique: The Malagos Garden Resort management has some explaining to do. How come the 20+ works of National Artist Napoleon Abueva, scattered around the park, are so poorly maintained that...More

After visiting the Eagle Center, go to its neighbor, Malagos Garden Resort. They serve great food and their own cheese. The Garden itself is huge and there are lots to do for children. Go to the Butterfly Pavilion. And dont forget to visit the Orchid...More

Pros: 1) Good for kids and family; strolling the grounds was fun 2) Friendly and helpful staff 3) Good playground, lots of other activities to do (horse-back riding, bird watching and feeding, etc). 4) Great collection of animals that the children really loved. 5) Free...More

The place is very lush and green. Napoleon Abueva's artworks are displayed everywhere. Bird show led by Doc Bo was very educational and entertaining. I think they only have it every Sunday. Make sure you buy the famous bignay wine for P300+. Entrance fee including...More

Hi all, we stayed here a week or so ago as we were operating int he area. I have stayed here before or just breezed through to order lunch with friends. The food is good but the service is very very slow. You'd die of thirst or hunger of you didn't rush them. The staff are good, well groomed polite and very accommodating to your requests. The area is perfectly maintained and being a green thumb I can appreciate their efforts and thank them for it. It's a well thought out and appointed little resort in a safe and peaceful area of Calinan.  A great little get away that when you close your eyes and listen to the abundant sounds of nature, you can transcend to any mountainous area of the globe. I like that a lot. The menu is good but could do with a change every 3 months to keep it lively, well priced for the area and having Mastercard facility is great. Heaps of things for kids of all ages and a solace for a good bottle of red and a cheese, crackers and fruit platter for mum and dad in any one of the numerous private seating areas across the property.  There's a drop off area right in front of the entrance steps and heaps of secure guarded and fenced parking across the road. The accommodation is clean with hot and cold water in the showers with a verandah off each room. The air-con is COLD for those that love living in a freezer like I do.  If you dont like the air-con then there's a nice breeze off the verandah that compliments the mountain creek that flows at the rear of the property.  This creek is fresh drinkable water and has been landscaped so you can sit on the side on the soft grass with a snack and talk about nothing or just listen to the water.   There's more to this place than meets the eye or what I have written, what you need to do is find out for yourself. Would I recommend a stay here? Absolutely, will I be back there, you bet!!

ReviewTitle: Drove all the way for nothing
Review: The place is a big garden but not a very well maintained one. It is in a state of disarray since not many people were visiting so the upkeep is suffering. It was a mistake driving all the way and paying a 100 bucks for nothing.

ReviewTitle: A Family Friendly Place to stay in
Review: The place is not as large as other garden resorts, but the staff is very helpful and everything is conveniently situated walking distance from everything.  The food is nothing spectacular but is worth the price that they sell it at. The Bird Show is something you shouldn't miss when you go to this garden.

Malagos Garden Resort is a nice place especially for kids since it is very educational. The animal show is also entertaining and fun. Nice place and nice food too. I love the goat's milk there especially the blueberry flavored milk. Would definitely bring friends over

Malagos Garden Resort is much smaller compared to the Eden Nature Park. Using various themes, Malagos Gardens are "separated" by several themes - butterfly, Noah's Arc, orchids, etc. They also have two restaurants where one can buy their meals.  Located across the street is the other part of the Garden where one can buy plants for sale.   Join a group tour to visit the Malagos Garden Resort, and other tour sites of Davao such as the Eagle Center, Japanese Tunnel, and Crocodile Park. These sites are far from the center of the city. Rates ranged from PHP 2,500 to PHP 3, 000.00 for vehicles that can accommodate 1-6 passengers.

We loved Malagos Garden Resort. We were only there for a day trip, and it was too bad our children were tired and sleepy. If there were a place where they could have taken a nap, we would have stayed longer. I would have loved for them to make the most of the horseback riding, petting zoo and kiddie ziplines. They did jump on the trampoline, ride the horse-drawn carriage, climb up the tree house and my daughter especially loved the butterfly sanctuary where she read all about the butterflies and saw them up close.  The food at the cafe was also very very good. We will definitely come back.

It takes 45 minutes to an hour to drive to Malagos Garden Resort from Davao City town proper. To maximize your trip, do your best to get there before the Bird Show begins at 10:30AM Sunday. Note: it's quite a walk from the entrance all the way to the venue for the actual bird show. The garden entrance fee costs 125 pesos which includes the bird show. We were glad we opted for the entrance fee with buffet lunch---at 275 pesos per person, we thoroughly enjoyed the surprisingly good food:) Doctor Bo (very knowledgeable veterinarian) runs the hour-long Bird Show which is both informative and entertaining. You may take pictures with wonderful birds after the show. And there are lots of nooks and crannies in this graden to find and explore, like large chess pieces, pleasant swings, etc.etc. There's a store opposite the buffet hall where you can buy Durian Jam, Honey, Brown eggs, Goat cheese, and ice cream at decent prices. It certainly was worth the effort to come here!

ReviewTitle: Perfect shot for your memorable event
Review: The place is so serene and quite. I like the way they arrange their garden and scenic spot. Its reminds me something abroad (Botanical Garden at Singapore). What I enjoy most is their butterfly farm and butterfly museum. I didn't know that we have a variety of those beautiful species and only endemic to Philippines. Wish we had check-in at that place but instead only take their day tour package.

Very spacious, carefully planned, good and comfy accommodations, interesting menu and many special deli items, great variety and healthy birds and animals. excellent landscape with a very good collection of plants. Very well thought of bird show

two things set malagos apart from other mountain resorts: 1. napoleon abueva works - this guy is a national artist. so it is quite awesome to see a lot of his work outside of a museum, installed all over the resort. 2. cheeses - malagos makes awesome local cheeses. really delicious at reasonable rates.
Very relaxing environment. Rooms comfortable and spacious. Plenty of room to wander and explore.

this is a really beautiful place, except i think it needs an upgrade to its run down condition. the rooms weren't thoroughly cleaned... breakfast took like an hour to serve - and was incomplete :( the bird show was great though... the host was very...More
My kids love this place they enjoyed the horse carraige ride, love the butterfly sanctuary.
the food is very fresh one of the best places I have eaten, very affordable and the best restaurant view in asia

Very enjoyable tour around the resort. Collection of plants very impressive. Feeding the birds, goose and duck was a first for me and very good interactive program for children. Getting near the ostrich and horse was an unforgettable experience.

The bird show was cool! It was an hour of education and fun. The birds were really the main attraction. There were parrots, chickens, hawks and ostriches. They served a lunch buffet. The food is not exceptional but very filling. They have a make your...More

malagos garden resort is a pleasant place to take the family to. a lot of wonderful plants and birds. malagos also has a good restaurant and a swimming pool. location suitable for a day trip, can also be combined with a visit to the Philippine...More

We went to this Malagos Garden Resort as recommended by my niece, Grace and Donny Lim on Sep 1, 2010. We were not disappointed because we saw all kinds of orchids, plants, trees, butterfly and other attractions. Although some of these attractions similar to what...More

ReviewTitle: I love the bird show and butterfly sanctuary
Review: I love going back to this place. At the start we watched a bird show then after that we roamed around the Malagos Garden Resort. After how many hours of taking pictures and sightseeing, we stopped by to eat. I love mangosteen and rambutan. Its...More

Went for lunch, which I thought would be a nice one since this is a farm! We were offered a fixed menu (uninteresting choices). When we got to the restaurant, we found out that there was a more extensive menu with more choices. I guess...More

We stayed there for a night during good friday.   First of all, the parking space was terrible, we had to park across the street and bring again our luggage back on the other side of the highway where the lobby is located.   Secondly, the rooms/cottages need MAJOR renovation. They were outdated and the facilities are poor (tiny t.v. WITHOUT cable, no fridge--they charge an additional cost if you want to have one in your room). The bathroom was ugly too, and right now the only word I can think of describe it is eww.   Next to it, the restaurant were we dined in (Koi Cafe) had so many flies and when we got there they didn't even had a menu! We had to wait for them to pick-up a copy from their other restaurant (near the lobby). Food choices were limited and the food we chose wasn't even available! A plus for them though was the ostrich salpicao with mashed potatoes on the side and malagos fried rice.   Lastly, the resort had very very poor maintenance, some attractions didn't even had a standby employee or assigned person to facilitate guests (e.g. petting zoo--kids wanted to pet the miniature horse but unfortunately no one was there to supervise). The "main" attraction of the place which were waling-waling and orchids were limited and non-existent. Some of the grasses need to be trimmed so we can actually walk on it.  In conclusion, although it is a cheap alternative for a resort, the management really should consider renovating the place and actually maintaining some of their amenities in order to attract more tourists and locals.

My boyfriend and I have just returned to HK after a week in the Philippines, during which we spent 3 days and 2 nights in Davao at the Malagos Garden Resort. Our aim in Davao was to visit the Philippine Eagle Foundation research facility, and we were informed that Malagos is the only hotel in the area close to the PEF camp, so that's where we stayed.  Let me say at the beginning that if you plan to do or see anything else in Davao other than the Philippine Eagle camp, then it's best to stay elsewhere. Malagos Garden is approximately an hour's drive from the city, which in a taxi will cost you P350 each way. The Philippine Eagle camp, a 10-minute drive from Malagos, and which is definitely worth a visit, can be seen in a single day-trip from the city; this leaves you other options for things to do in Davao before and after you've seen the PEF facilities, as there is really nothing, zero, zilch around that area other than the PEF. (Good for the eagles, not so good for visitors looking for stuff to do & see!)  As for the hotel itself ... it's a rip-off. It seems it has come under new management (the daughter of the owner runs it now) and they seem intent to squeeze every last peso from everyone who walks through their shabby doors. The place has massive grounds around it, having been a farm in a past life apparently. The gardens however have that look of being unkempt and overgrown. Their "butterfly garden" is a series of small netted enclosures with more overgrown plants and, as far as we could tell, only one species of butterfly in them. There is, however, an abandoned shack with an ancient, unstocked bar that looks like no one has used it in 20 years, containing someone's large collection of preserved and mounted butterflies. Not exactly our idea of a butterfly garden.  When we first tried to book our room online, we inquired about airport pick-up and they said that one-way airport transfer was P2500. That price was more than the cost of one night's stay (P2400 for a "Multi-Family Cottage Room"), which rather surprised us. I sent an email to our contact at the Philippine Eagle Foundation asking how much a cab from the airport normally costs and they put it as coming between P300-P500. We then cancelled the airport transfer arrangement and took a cab to the hotel which by meter came up to P345. Malagos was prepared to charge us over 5 times the going rate! That left a bad taste in our mouths, but we were still prepared to keep an open mind at this point.  The hotel insists on checking inside the bags of everyone who comes in, day visitors (who still pay P100/person for the privilege of walking around the grounds) and staying guests alike. When we arrived it was 7pm and the main entrance had been closed for the day. The night guard let us in through a side entrance and as we waited for the transport to take us to the room, he asked to check inside our bags. We complied, thinking that this was a security measure, like those taken most places in the Philippines, to prevent acts of terrorism. As the guard poked through the contents of our bag, he asked if we had any food in it. Puzzled, we said no. He immediately waved us through then. "Is that what you were looking for? Food?" I asked, incredulous. He said yes. Having been in parks in bear countries where it's dangerous to have food lying around, I asked if it was to protect us from wildlife. No, he said, it just wasn't allowed to bring any food inside because there was a restaurant within the premises! We were shocked at this policy, but we found out the next day that they were quite serious about it as when we returned from the PEF we had a couple of pomelos that we'd bought from a roadside stand. Both the guard and the guy behind the desk at reception initially wouldn't let us take them back to our room with us! I asked if they actually had pomelo at their restaurant, and they said no. So why couldn't we take our pomelo in, considering they couldn't sell it to us even if they wanted to? I demanded to see the manager, but after a quick phone call the reception guy said the manager "would allow it this time". Their policy is even more ridiculous considering how poorly-stocked their restaurant is. They have no fresh milk (only non-dairy creamer for coffee), a very limited selection of drinks and snacks, several items we tried to order off the menu were not available (including coconut - bizarre considering the compound had scores of coconut trees with visibly-ready coconuts!), and heaven help the poor soul who gets peckish after 8pm because the restaurant closes at 8 o'clock.  The room we got was run-down, dark and monastic, with a single crucifix on the wall and nothing else. But the A/C worked and it was clean, at least, except for the closet which was dank and smelled of mold. We kept all our clothes in our suitcase. The room sleeps four, with pull-out mattresses under the twin beds, so if four of you are staying in one room I guess the cost of it evens out at P600 per person. For a couple at P1200 per person though, it's definitely not worth it, even with breakfast included (the breakfast is pretty basic anyway, nothing to write home about).  The staff seem friendly enough, and seem mostly embarrassed and apologetic at management policies. Mostly.  Another thing to watch out for is booking a cab to take you back to the airport. We asked the front desk to arrange a taxi to drive us to the airport, but instead they arranged for a private car with a guy who apparently runs city tours of Davao. We found this out when we rang reception the morning of our departure and were told the price for the car to the airport was P600. We asked why, when the metered rate on the way in was under P400? They said that was what the guy charged. That's when we found out it was a private car. We immediately cancelled that booking (to the very obvious consternation of the reception guy) and arranged for a taxi. It's not that we were being tight, (despite the meter coming to just below P400 on both our taxi rides to and from the airport, we gave our drivers P500 anyway) but we resented the feeling that we were being milked for every last cent they could get from us.   So the upshot is: stay in the city, where you have a wider choice of hotels and activities, and just do a day-trip to the Philippine Eagle facilities. The Crown Recency have the same room rate as Malagos Gardens, and they're a proper hotel!

ReviewTitle: Cheap, filling lunch and attractive gardens
Review: My friends and I used the resort for lunch after visiting the Philippine Eagle Centre which is close by.  The resort has a small entrance fee. Its gardens are pleasant and apparently set on 12 hectares though we only walked a small portion of them.  There is an interactive bird show on Sundays at 1030 but we missed it by two hours.   The butterfly sanctuary was pleasant although just a little run down. We only saw two or three differently coloured butterfly species: a few of each, and none were overly spectacular or irridescent.  Service in the restaurant was slow but the bill for a couple of refreshing iced teas each and a filling main chicken dish with rice came to only P2000 for four, or about A$22, so no one could complain.  I could not see any sign of what some sites claim is accommodation but perhaps I looked in the wrong part of the resort.  Our taxi driver waited happily while we ate.

This is the first time in my life that i stayed in a garden resort. Malagos resort is a different experience for me. In this resort, there's a bird sanctuary, garden-filled park, lots of trees and other plants i never heard of, there's tons of fish ponds in the resort, you will see different kinds of ducks and birds roaming around the resort. The food is very good. You can buy fish, meat and veggies in the market and you can ask the resort to cook it for you. Room are not so good but its very cheap and comfortable. The people in the resort is very friendly. Overall, the place is fine, its not so luxurious, the place looks old but clean. There's also a pool and a gift shop.
